title: How Operation Matterhorn shifted 140,000 passengers in 150 planes using airlines you've never heard of
text:
The repatriation of over 140,000 stranded Thomas Cook passengers, dubbed ‘Operation Matterhorn’, concluded today.

The programme was planned in such a way that anyone on a two-week holiday, even those that began only hours before Thomas Cook collapsed on September 23, could continue to relax as if nothing had changed.

Therefore many thousands of British holidaymakers have spent the last fortnight doing just that, slumped by the pool while the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has scrambled to organise the biggest peacetime repatriation in British history.

In total the UK Government has flown back 140,000 stranded Thomas Cook customers from 53 destinations in 17 countries around the world as far...
